docs.lead_paragraph: A growing consensus in favor of Truvada is opposed by one vocal man, Michael Weinstein, and his nonprofit organization.

headline.main: AIDS Group Wages Lonely Fight Against Pill to Prevent H.I.V.
headline.print_headline: Drug to Lower H.I.V. Risk Has Lone Public Naysayer

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Michael Weinstein, president of Los Angeles-based nonprofit AIDS Healthcare Foundation, speaks out against use of Truvada to prevent HIV with national ad campaign; warns widespread use of drug erodes condom use and leaves many open to infection; Weinstein also notes that research found many people were not consistently taking Truvada and therefore risking HIV infection.
docs.snippet: A growing consensus in favor of Truvada is opposed by one vocal man, Michael Weinstein, and his nonprofit organization.

docs.lead_paragraph: Washington state's health insurance exchange was back up and running Sunday after shutting down for a day because of a glitch involving tax credit calculations.

headline.main: Washington State Health Exchange Is Working Again
headline.print_headline: Washington State Health Exchange Is Working Again

docs.snippet: Washington state's health insurance exchange was back up and running Sunday after shutting down for a day because of a glitch involving tax credit calculations.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. President Barack Obama on Sunday defended the transparency of his signature healthcare law, after one of the White House's advisers on the reform said the law passed, in part, because of the "stupidity" of American voters.

headline.main: Obama Defends Healthcare Law After Adviser Criticism
headline.print_headline: Obama Defends Healthcare Law After Adviser Criticism

docs.snippet: U.S. President Barack Obama on Sunday defended the transparency of his signature healthcare law, after one of the White House's advisers on the reform said the law passed, in part, because of the "stupidity" of American voters.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state that served as a template for President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act had so much trouble coordinating with the federal government that it became a model of another sort: ineptitude.

headline.main: States Working to Fix Hobbled Health Care Websites
headline.print_headline: States Working to Fix Hobbled Health Care Websites

docs.snippet: The state that served as a template for President Barack Obama's Affordable Care Act had so much trouble coordinating with the federal government that it became a model of another sort: ineptitude.

docs.lead_paragraph: As a crucial second sign-up season gears up, the Obama administration said Sunday that HealthCare.gov is stable and working well, a far cry from last year's frozen computer screens and frustrated customers.
docs.snippet: As a crucial second sign-up season gears up, the Obama administration said Sunday that HealthCare.gov is stable and working well, a far cry from last year's frozen computer screens and frustrated customers.

docs.lead_paragraph: The death of a parent brought Makia Green, a college student, mounting needs and surprises. But she inherited her mother’s drive, persistence and devotion to education.

headline.main: Drawing Strength From the Gifts Her Mother Left Behind
headline.print_headline: Drawing Strength From the Gifts Her Mother Left Behind

docs.abstract: Children’s Aid Society, one of seven agencies supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, helps Makia Green pay for school supplies and tuition, as well as funeral services for her mother.
docs.snippet: The death of a parent brought Makia Green, a college student, mounting needs and surprises. But she inherited her mother’s drive, persistence and devotion to education.

keywords.value: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Demographics will not save them. A vision might.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by author Kevin Baker warns Democrats against relying on shifting demographics in the country to reliably give them a governing majority; notes that past three midterms have been disastrous for Democrats; calls on Democrats to offer voters a bold vision that will appeal to working men and women.
docs.snippet: Demographics will not save them. A vision might.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Republican economic approach could still revolve around cutting taxes, but the cuts would no longer be focused on the affluent.

headline.main: How the G.O.P. Can Court the Working Class
headline.print_headline: How the G.O.P. Can Court the Working Class

docs.abstract: The Upshot; one intriguing question heading into 2016 presidential campaign is how serious Republicans are about trying to change their constituency and attract more Americans from lower income brackets; party has focused on tax cuts for the wealthy for decades, but a focus on cutting taxes for struggling middle class could broaden party's appeal.
docs.snippet: A new Republican economic approach could still revolve around cutting taxes, but the cuts would no longer be focused on the affluent.

docs.lead_paragraph: The system opened Saturday and performed much better than last year, but some consumers reported long delays in trying to buy insurance and access their accounts at HealthCare.gov.

headline.main: Some New Frustrations as Health Exchange Opens
headline.print_headline: Some New Frustrations as Health Exchange Opens

docs.abstract: Federal health insurance marketplace opens for business and performs much better than in 2013, but some consumers report long, frustrating delays in trying to buy insurance and gain access to their accounts at HealthCare.gov.
docs.snippet: The system opened Saturday and performed much better than last year, but some consumers reported long delays in trying to buy insurance and access their accounts at HealthCare.gov.

byline.contributor: Mauricio Guerrero contributed reporting from Houston, Matt Hamilton from Los Angeles and Colin Moynihan from New York.
byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ABBY GOODNOUGH

docs.lead_paragraph: An electrical device glued to the scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with the deadliest type of brain tumor, glioblastoma, researchers have found.

headline.main: Electrical Scalp Device Can Slow Progression of Deadly Brain Tumors
headline.print_headline: Electrical Scalp Device for Deadliest Brain Tumors Can Prolong Survival

docs.abstract: Researchers report that electrical device glued to scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with deadliest type of brain tumor, called glioblastomas; device, produced by British company Novocure, is not cure and on average adds only a few more months of life when paired with standard regimen of surgery, radiation and chemotherapy; findings were presented at meeting of Society for Neuro-Oncology.
docs.snippet: An electrical device glued to the scalp can slow cancer growth and prolong survival in people with the deadliest type of brain tumor, glioblastoma, researchers have found.
